The  objectives  are  to  create  a  dynamic  SME  sector,  enhance  its
capabilities  and  competitiveness,  create  jobs  and,  in  doing  so,
reduce  poverty.  These  objectives  are  to  be  achieved  through  an
integrated approach that

(i)  strengthens the enabling business environment for SMEs,

(ii)  catalyzes investment by improving SMEs access to finance

through commercial channels, and

(iii) enhances 

the  capacity  of 

the  Sri  Lankan  business
development  services  (BDS)  sector  to  efficiently  and
effectively deliver services to SMEs.

The  Program  comprises  (i)  a  program  of  policy  reforms;  (ii)  a
project  to  finance  a  BDS  support  facility  –  the  Business  Services
Support  Facility  (BSSF);  (iii)  a  line  of  credit  each  to  Sampath
Bank,  Commercial  Bank  of  Ceylon  (CBC),  Hatton  National  Bank

The  Sector  Development  Program  will  set  in  place  a  strategy  for
SME  development  through  the  completion  of  a  SME  policy  white
paper  by  a  SME  task  force;  establish  a  SME  Policy  Unit  to
address  future  SME-related  policy  and  regulatory  issues,  and
support  an  institutional  response—the  Deregulation  Committee—
for  identifying  and  implementing  of  further  policy  and  institutional
reforms  needed  to  achieve  competitiveness.  ICT  use  will  be
promoted  as  a  way  to  link  SMEs  with  the  global  economy  and
reduce  their  costs  of  accessing  information  and  markets.  A  BDS

complemented  by  measures  to  promote  market  and  institutional
development  for  SME  finance.  The  market  for  financing  will  be
promoted  by  legal  reform  that  creates  a  level  playing  field,

In 2000, the Government of Sri Lanka requested the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s)
assistance  to  strengthen  the  performance  of  the  SME  sector  as  part  of  ongoing  efforts  to
improve  competitiveness,  and  promote  greater
liberalize  and  diversify 
employment  and  growth.  An  advisory  TA  for  SME  development  was  approved  in  December
2000.1  A  survey  of  300  SMEs  was  conducted  under  the  TA,  as  were  a  number  of  diagnostic
studies.  The  findings  of  the  studies  indicate  that  the  main  requirements  of  SME  development
are (i) an improved business environment through deregulation and reform of appropriate laws,
regulations,  and  institutions  that  either  favor  large  firms  or  act  as  impediments  to  business  in
general; (ii) better access by SMEs to business services provided by private sector providers so
as  to  overcome  deficiencies  in  capabilities  and  access  to  markets  and  technology;  and  (iii)
improved  access  to  finance  at  market  terms  to  catalyze  investments.  The  diagnostics  also
stressed the importance of institutional capacity for developing a coordinated strategy for SME
support,  currently  absent  in  Sri  Lanka,  and  the  need  to  apply  the  test  of  sustainability  to  all
policy and institutional interventions. The findings are consistent with international best practice,
which has moved from a focus on provision of subsidized credit and TA to SMEs, to one which
stresses  market  forces  and  fee-based  services  within  a  strategic  framework  that  links  policy
reform, access to credit, and capacity building.

The assessment of the SME sector in Sri Lanka was undertaken in an environment that

4.
As  a  result  of  the  changes,  the  potential  for  attracting  foreign  direct  investment  has
increased, as have opportunities for developing new products and geographic markets. At the

imbedded  in  a  global  context.  In  fact,  a  clear  role  for  policy  makers  is  to  provide  an  enabling
environment that supports dynamic firms seeking to make investment decisions in response to
opportunities in domestic and international markets.

III. 

THE SECTOR

6.
Following  a  number  of  years  of  growth  at  about  5  percent  per  annum,  economic
performance  slowed  in  2001,  with  the  growth  rate  expected  to  fall  to  about  1  percent.  This  is
largely  the  result  of  external  factors  including  higher  oil  prices,  slower  growth  in  the  world
economy  and  adverse  weather  conditions  that  have  affected  agriculture.  A  further  blow  to  the
economy  was  the  decline  in  tourism  revenues  following  the  attack  on  Colombo  airport  in  July
2001.  This  trend  could  be  exacerbated  in  the  aftermath  of  the  terrorist  attacks  in  the  United
States  if  this,  along  with  other  factors,  leads  to  a  further  slowdown  in  the  world  economy.  In
parallel  with  measures  being  implemented  in  developed  economies,  the  Government  is
preparing  a  package  of  stimulus  measures,  which,  by  promoting  greater  investment  and

However, the country’s macroeconomic imbalances are a cause for continuing concern

reserves. To address these imbalances, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved a 14-

B. 

Sector Description and Recent Performance

8.
Sri  Lanka  benefited  from  the  shift  in  the  late  1970s  from  a  strategy  of  inward-oriented,
public-sector-led  growth  to  one  which  stressed  growth  of  the  private  sector  and  greater
openness  to  the  international  economy.  The  liberalization  of  the  economy  which  followed  was
supported by a variety of measures to promote exports and divest the public sector’s ownership
in a wide range of sectors through the 1980s and much of the 1990s.

9.
The sustained liberalization of the economy was accompanied by high investment levels
and accumulation of capital, increased productivity, and strong employment growth, especially
in  private  sector  manufacturing.  By  1993,  productivity  in  the  private  manufacturing  sector  had
surpassed that in the public sector. The gain in productivity was due partly to increased use of
inputs such as labor and capital, and partly to improvements in technical or total productivity—or
the  efficiency  with  which  the  inputs  of  capital  and  labor  were  used.  Thus,  during  1977-1998,

The  decades  of  reform  have  led  to  significant  structural  change  in  the  economy.  As  a

industry remains an important sector, particularly when measured by recent changes in output.
This pattern is typical of middle-level developing countries.

11. While  SMEs  have  benefited  from  reforms  and  economic  growth,  many  still    exhibit  a
relatively  low  level  of  technology,  and  poor  management,  financial  and  accounting  practices.
They also face significant difficulties in accessing information, markets and finance.  Limitations
in capacity are compounded by a business and regulatory environment that raises costs and still
provides unnecessary hurdles to the establishment and operation of businesses.

The  performance  of  SMEs  is  not  easy  to  measure  as  definitions  of  SMEs  have  varied
12.
considerably  over  the  years  and  among  institutions.  The  present  analysis  shows  that  the
business  sector  in  Sri  Lanka  is  divided  into  the  following:  (i)  small-scale  enterprises  with  5-49
employees,  (ii)  medium-scale  enterprises  with  50-149  employees,  and  (iii)  large  scale
enterprises with more than 150 employees. On this basis, and in terms of the ISIC classification
of  industries,  SMEs  are  found  in  all  subsectors  of  the  economy  with  a  concentration  in
manufacturing  sector  activities.    SMEs  are  widely  spread  across  urban,  rural,  and  estate
sectors. Within the urban sector their presence is predominantly in secondary and tertiary type
economic  activities,  while  in  the  rural  and  estate  sectors  they  are  heavily  concentrated  in
primary and secondary type economic activities.

13.
In manufacturing, SMEs account for 95 percent of establishments, 25 percent of output
and 34 percent of employment. If knitting and wearing apparel are subtracted—both subsectors
with large-scale producers—the SME share of employment in the manufacturing sector rises to
49 percent of the total. Thirty percent of SMEs produce for export markets. There are numerous
small  exporters,  and  the  share  of  value  added  by  SMEs  is  high  in  sectors  where  the  ratio  of
exports  to  total  production  is  high.  A  similar  result  holds  with  skilled  labor:  sectors  with  high
skilled  labor  inputs  are  those  in  which  SMEs  have  a  high  proportion  of  value  added.3  This
suggests  a  relatively  dynamic  sector,  something  confirmed  by  the  ADB  survey  findings  that
show that two thirds of SMEs consider themselves to be profitable.

On the other hand, medium-size firms account for only 6 percent of establishments—the

and employment in the SME sector have declined since 1983, from 30 percent and 47 percent

into larger firms. In Indonesia, 25 percent of the output of large firms is found to be that of firms

2. 

High Transaction Costs

17.
SMEs  experience  difficulties  with  the  complexity  of  the  regulatory  framework.  A
significant number of firms cite the need to make unofficial payments. Medium and large firms
assign an average of two full-time staff to deal with regulatory compliance issues. The cost of
complying with the regulatory framework, in terms of both time and money 4 shows the economy
suffers from high transaction costs, both in starting new companies and operating existing ones.
A recent cross-country study of 75 countries found that starting a company imposed a cost of
about 9 percent of per capita gross domestic product (GDP) in Sri Lanka in terms of compliance
costs and use of time. In contrast, in most middle income countries, this cost was found to be
about 1-2 percent of per capita GDP. This cost is negligibly small in developed economies. At
the country specific level, ADB’s studies show that an average of 82 days is needed to obtain all
clearances to start a business (although in practice firms do not wait for the official clearance to
start)  at  an  average  cost  of  about  SLRs5,800.  Both  the  international  and  the  ADB  studies
suggest that these costs are the result of a regulatory structure that has evolved in response to
opportunities  to  generating  additional  income  for  state  functionaries.  For  SMEs,  this  difficulty
tends to be in respect of getting approvals for environmental issues, connections to utility, etc.,
much of which is facilitated for large firms by the Board of Investment (BOI).

18.
Large firms are better able to handle transaction costs and are able to spread them over
a larger output base. SMEs are less able to do this and suffer disproportionately, leading many
to opt out of the formal sector or choose to remain small. Transaction costs thus influence the
size of firms: in high-cost economies firms choose to integrate vertically and thus do internally a
range  of  activities  which,  in  a  more  transparent  regulatory  framework,  they  would  have

3.  Complex Incentive Structure

19.
The  tax  system  in  Sri  Lanka  is  a  crucial  element  of  the  incentive  structure.  Given  the
complexity  and  uncertainty  of  the  present  tax  system,  many  small  firms  choose  to  remain
informal. For such firms the key issues are high transactions costs from the system of archaic
stamp duties that cover both imports and domestic goods, tax rates that are higher than rates
available to large firms, and complexity that leads to uncertainty as well as procedural difficulties
in compliance.

20.
Stamp  duties  are  inefficient  tax  instruments.  They  are  levied  on  all  instruments  and
documents required for proof of a transaction in Sri Lanka. Some 39 categories of stamp duties
exist  for  bank  checks,  bills  of  exchange,  travelers  checks,  credit  cards,  mortgages,  insurance
policies, salaries, commercial invoices, construction contracts, bonds, bank guarantees, etc. All
could be eliminated with major improvements in efficiency. About 60 percent of revenues from
stamp duties are collected (by Customs) on letters of credit and commercial invoices and from
issue of Treasury Stamps.

21.
Tax and investment incentives and exemptions are announced in the budget, sometimes
provided  under  the  auspices  of  the  Inland  Revenue  Act  by  the  Treasury,  and  sometimes
through the BOI Act. The budget frequently leaves unclear the authority for the provision of the
incentive. BOI has some 23 categories of firms and sectors  that receive incentives in the form
of lower corporate tax rates, duty exemptions, and tax holidays of various lengths. The Treasury
provides  a  similar  range  of  incentives  for  a  similarly  wide  range  of  sectors.    These  incentives
typically  cannot  be  accessed  by  SMEs,  resulting  in  a  situation  in  which  SMEs  are  liable  to
higher corporate tax rates than paid by most large firms.

22.
The  most  serious  effect  of  the  complex  incentive  structure  is  in  terms  of  allocation
efficiency; investment activity is distorted between investments favored and not, and there is no
level playing field. This issue is especially relevant given the use of different rules for different
companies.  The  current  incentive  structure  also  imposes  great  administrative  strain.  The
administrative  capacity  at  the  Inland  Revenue  Department  (IRD)  is  particularly  limited,  with
many enterprises benefiting from tax holidays not even filing income tax returns, and the office
has difficulty in keeping track of incentives.

23.
The  system  of  direct  taxes  includes  the  National  Security  Levy  and  the  Financial
Institutions Levy. Revenue from the National Security Levy accounts for 2.7 percent of GDP; for
the Financial Institutions Levy, it is 0.1 percent of GDP; and that the turnover retail tax by the
provincial  councils,  0.15  percent  of  GDP.  Turnover  taxes  increase  the  incentive  for  vertical
integration of activities within firms. In contrast, the goods and services tax (GST) is a VAT-style

tax.  A  major  policy  objective  of  tax  policy  reform  is  to  eliminate  turnover  taxes,  increase  the
GST,  and  expand  its  coverage  by  eliminating  the  sectors  that  are  currently  exempted
(electricity, public transportation, petroleum, and agriculture).

4. 

Tax Administration and Public Sector Governance

24.
Both  SMEs  and  large  firms  cite  tax  administration  and  the  customs  as  major
impediments to doing business. The IRD’s outdated organizational structure focuses on type of
tax,  rather  than  function,  and  prevents  specialization  and  improvement  of  skills.  This
organizational  structure  and  a  fragmented  computer  system  impede  communication  within  the
organization  and  reduce  productivity.  The  high  status  of  specific  departments  (e.g.,  Large
Taxpayer Unit) affects staffing problems and morale, and transfers result in loss of accumulated
skills.  Many  units  lack  staff,  and  many  others  lack  skilled  workers.  Outdated  administrative
procedures  and  weak  enforcement  mechanisms  have  resulted  in  low  compliance  and  very
limited success in widening the tax net and in pursuing defaulters. The tax net has been eroded
through exemptions, especially those provided by BOI. There is duplication in key activities and
services that IRD and Customs provide.  The public has a poor perception of IRD.

25.

drawbacks and failures of previous reform efforts in Sri Lanka and elsewhere. Shortcomings in
the traditional model of civil service reform has led to the recognition that insufficient attention
has been paid to appropriately structuring incentives within the public sector and in building up

number  of  developing  and  developed  economies,  which  have  stressed  the  importance  of
autonomous, professionally run, and performance-based public sector institutions in promoting
the productivity of the private sector. The key principles emerging from this experience follows:

Limited Market for Strengthening Business Capabilities

27.
Promoting the demand and efficient supply of business development services (BDS) is
critical to ensuring a dynamic SME sector.5 The demand  varies across sectors, and is strongest
in the textiles, wearing apparel, and leather sector. Most SMEs value the use of BDS for project
preparation. Smaller firms prefer to seek BDS support for long-term issues such as marketing
and gaining access to technology. Available BDS support ranges from traditional forms of class
room  training  on  entrepreneurship  and  marketing  to  sophisticated  attempts  to  foster  public-
private partnerships in providing of business information services. While there are schemes for
different types of SMEs (starters, non-growers/slow growers, and fast growers), there does not
appear  to  be  an  overall  strategy  that  aims  at  developing  assistance  packages  in  accordance
with the needs of specific types of SMEs. Broadly, Government agencies are most prominent in
to  starters  and  non-growers/slow  growers,  while  nongovernment
providing  support 
organizations  (NGOs)  concentrate  on  microenterprises  with  the  business  chambers  playing  a
more important role in providing assistance to fast-growing firms.

Most Government programs can be characterized as pilot projects with a limited number

resources  not  allowing  for  return  visits  and  further  support  at  a  later  stage.  Outreach  and
participation rates of these programs remain low, especially in the rural areas. Based on direct
delivery  of  services,  these  schemes  do  not  charge  fees  and  therefore  have  no  credible
mechanism for feedback, assessment of impact, or redesign. They are primarily supply driven
and are unable to provide SMEs with the services they value. Similarly, aid-funded programs—
even  those  that  provide  assistance  to  BDS  providers—have  often  tended  to  be  supply-driven
and dependent on subsidized funds. This has resulted in the source of finance - the aid agency
- being seen as the ultimate client, rather than the SMEs. Organizations such as associations
and  chambers  of  commerce  are  not  always  clear  on  their  role  in  promoting  SME  growth,
particularly whether or not they should stimulate the use of BDS or deliver BDS services. These
institutions are missing an opportunity to play a critical, beneficial, and financially rewarding role
in brokering the use of BDS by their members.

29.
Partly because the sector is receiving considerable external support, there is reasonably
widespread  access  to  BDS  throughout  the  country.  In  addition,  some  aid  agencies  are  now

7.

Market and Institutional Development for Sustainable Finance

a. 

Banks and Other Institutions

33.
The Sri Lankan financial sector has 27 commercial banks, 42 depository institutions (a
national savings bank, 24 finance companies, and 17 regional rural development banks), three
state-sponsored  long-term  financial  institutions  (2  DFIs  and  one  state  mortgage  bank)  six
insurance companies and two public pension funds. The commercial banks comprise 2 state, 7
local,  and  18  foreign  banks.  During  the  last  decade,  the  financial  sector  represented  a
substantial  part  of  the  GDP  growing  to  more  than  10  percent  of  the  economy.  In  the  last  five
years, the commercial banks’ total assets grew from 14 to 18 percent annually from SLRs389.7
billion in 1996 to about SLRs678 billion in 2000. Total loan assets increased in about the same
annual  percentages  from  SLRs202.4  billion  in  1996  to  SLRs356.6  billion  in  2000.  Total
commercial  bank  deposits  also  increased  at  a  healthy  clip  from  SLRs261.9  billion  in  1996  to
SLRs445.6 billion at end-2000.

34.
State-owned banks hold almost 60 percent of total banking assets, and the five largest
private commercial banks hold more than 30 percent of the remainder. All compete for deposits
from the public. The state banks have a nationwide branch network, but remain highly inefficient
and  massively  undercapitalized.  The  major  private  commercial  banks  have  widened  their
networks  to  cover  almost  the  entire  country,  including  Jaffna.  The  three  leading  commercial
banks  –  Hatton  National  Bank  (HNB),  Commercial  Bank  of  Ceylon  (CBC)  and  Sampath  Bank
(SB)  have  over  200  branches  in  aggregate  nationwide.  CBC  and  Sampath  Bank  are  seeking
greater  prudential  safety  and  security  through  diversifying  what  were  once  loan  portfolios
concentrated in financing large enterprises. HNB has been an innovator in SME lending in Sri

 9

Lanka and one of the earliest to recognize that lending to SMEs can be profitable and provide a
cushion to the bank in times of economic decline.

b.

Absence of Level Playing Field for DFIs and Commercial Banks

35.
High  unit  lending  costs  to  SMEs  and  higher  perceived  risks  limit  bank  financing  to  the
sector.  Yet  international  experience  indicates  the  role  that  policy  reform  and  capacity  building
can  play  in  promoting  the  market  and  institutional  development  needed  to  ensure  sustainable
finance for SMEs at commercial terms. In terms of the market, the objective is to use a variety of
instruments—including  promotion  of  competition,  provisions  of  public  guarantees,  etc.—to
induce financial institutions to direct greater flows of financial resources on commercial terms to
meet  SME  needs.  In  terms  of  institutional  development,  the  objective  is  to  ensure  that  these
institutions  have  appropriate  lending  methodologies,  trained  staff,  ICT,  and  internal  incentive
systems to serve the market effectively.

36.
Market  and  institutional  development  requires  that  both  DFIs  and  private  commercial
banks  in  Sri  Lanka  are  equally  encouraged  to  provide  lines  of  credit  to  SMEs  without
discriminatory impediments to either DFIs or private banks. Historically, the DFIs have met the
SME sector’s credit needs but this is no longer sustainable and access needs to be widened to
the private commercial banking sector. The current legal environment in Sri Lanka poses some
impediments to this. Stemming from the Banking Act of 1988 (Act No. 30 of 1988) as amended,
DFIs  are  unable  to  provide  foreign  currency  loans  in  the  same  fashion  as  private  banks.  This
may have significance for purposes of lending to, for example, export-oriented SMEs that would
have demand for foreign currency loans. In this regard, the competitive pressures between DFIs
and private banks with regard to foreign currency loans to SMEs are artificially constrained by a
legal impediment that no longer matches the reality of the market-driven blurring of the lines in
the operations of DFIs and private banks.

The need for nondiscriminatory treatment of commercial banks and DFIs is underscored
37.
by the nature of institutional and market development in the financial sector in Sri Lanka. This is
characterized by an increasing blurring of the line between DFIs and private banks. Sri Lanka’s
DFIs  are  increasingly  moving  in  the  direction  of  universal  banking.  Thus,  the  National
Development  Bank  of  Sri  Lanka  (NDB)  has  taken  over  the  banking  operations  of  ABN  AMRO
Bank  in  Sri  Lanka  and  obtained  regulatory  approval  to  form  NDB  Bank  as  a  wholly  owned
subsidiary.  Second,  DFCC  Bank  (formerly  the  Development  Finance  Corporation  of  Ceylon)
owns  29.9  percent  of  CBC  and  the  Government  through  the  Insurance  Corporation  owns
another 29.9 percent of CBC, which is treated as a private bank. Second, in the context of SME
development, it will be necessary to channel credit by private banks to SMEs alongside the DFIs
credit  to  SMEs.  This  is  important  not  merely  in  terms  of  the  overall  credit  demands  of  the
potentially dynamic SME sector but also because of the need to allow SMEs to grow into larger
corporations in the portfolio of private banks.

38.
Commercial interests and competition for deposit and loan customers have led a number
of  the  commercial  banks  to  lend  more  aggressively  to  SMEs  despite  a  shortage  of  resources
available  to  do  so.  Banks  such  as  Sampath,  HNB  and  CBC  are  playing  a  leading  role  in  this
regard. These banks have developed several deposit products to reduce their matching risk for
this  lending.  There  are  now  time  deposit  mechanisms  that  allow  banks  to  fund  term  loan
facilities  of  five  years  or  longer  and  there  have  been  several  issues  of  debentures  by  PCIs.
Branch  networks  have  also  been  extended  into  rural  areas.  Although  encouraging,  these
resource mobilization activities will first and foremost fund activities that carry less relative risk

 10

for  the  banks,  such  as  housing  loans,  and  then  be  available  for  lending  to  SMEs.  Also,  their
volume is limited, given the relatively high short-term interest rates.

39.
Though  considerable  ground  remains  to  be  covered,  efforts  at  learning  about  SMEs,
physically locating branches closer to the areas of economic activity, and raising funding for on-
lending to SMEs are helping to mitigate the problem of access to finance. Despite these positive
developments,  bankers  still  report  a  dearth  of  bankable  deals  and  a  heavy  reliance  on  real
estate as security. Training in SME lending would benefit the PCIs. While PCIs have received
TA  over  the  years  in  lending  techniques  based  on  cash  flow,  such  training  tended  to
concentrate on structuring the loan repayments according to the projected cash flow; insufficient
attention was paid to the important skill of counseling. Additionally, there remains the problem of
high unit transaction costs in processing relatively small SME loans.

c.

Use of Information Technology and Credit Scoring

40.
Promoting  the  use  of  IT  and  credit  scoring  is  a  powerful  way  to  minimize  the  high
transaction  costs  associated  with  SME  loan  management,  a  key  constraint  to  greater  and
sustained lending to the sector.  Credit scoring software allows a bank to achieve a faster, more
consistent series of decisions and reduces bank administrative costs for smaller loans. Prudent
use  of  properly  developed  loan  scoring  methods  has  the  potential  to  reduce  loan  processing
time from 6 to 2 weeks down to a few days for most SME loans. The second benefit of credit-
scoring software is that it is a tool that promotes consistency across the bank. One danger of a
manual credit investigation process is that the final loan decision may be skewed by the internal
incentive system of a bank. For example, when bank staff members, such as loan officers and
bank  managers,  receive  financial  incentives  for  extending  new  loans,  they  will  frequently
concentrate on quantity rather than seek out quality loans with a high probability of repayment.
The use of credit-scoring technology can remove a substantial proportion of the discretion from
loan officers and branch managers, to the overall benefit of the institution.

41.
The  benefits  of  credit  scoring  are  maximized  through  use  of  integrated  computer
systems.  A  modern  computer  system  is  able  to  track  loan  quality  indicators  that  are  ordinarily
difficult to obtain in a timely manner by manual calculation. A useful indicator is the portfolio at
risk (PAR). PAR shows the quality of the loan portfolio and, by association, the effectiveness or
otherwise of the overall loan management policies of the bank. Well-managed banks have a low
PAR and vice versa. Systems such as Globus are able to track PAR on loans at individual loan
and branch levels. Globus also allows senior managers to directly review the PAR of the loan
accounts  of  the  responsible  loan  officer.  Importantly,  as  PAR  information  is  available  at  loan
officer  level,  it  is  relatively  straightforward  to  develop  an  incentive  system  that  links  PAR  to  a
loan officers/branch managers’ bonus scheme.

d.

Access to Nonbank Finance

42.
In the medium term, a dynamic SME sector will need access to not only bank finance,
but to nonbank finance as well. While the latter is often cheaper, it requires a legal provision for
the use of movables for collateral.  The absence in Sri Lanka of a modern legal framework for
creating,  prioritizing,  and  enforcing  of  security  interests  in  movable  property  (also  known  as  a
secured transactions legal framework) is a critical factor in the SMEs’ lack of access to readily
available, cheap, and long-term credit. This absence is particularly acute for SMEs, since they,
unlike  larger  enterprises,  are  less  likely  to  have  immovable  property  that  can  be  offered  as
collateral to secure loans from creditors.

 11

One  of  the  effects  of  the  lack  of  an  upgraded  secured  transactions  legal  framework  is
43.
that sources of credit are concentrated on bank credit since the legal system does not allow for
a diversified set of potential creditors, such as suppliers of goods, to take effective security over
movable  property.  Debtors  are  unable  to  use  their  inventories  and  accounts  receivable
effectively as collateral for credit from such nonbank creditors.

44.
A  review  of  recent  legal  reform  efforts  in  Sri  Lanka  indicates  that  such  efforts  have
focused  on  loan  enforcement  reforms  alone.  Thus  efforts  have  been  made  to  expedite  debt
recovery in the courts through reforms like the Hypothecary Action under Mortgage Act No. 6 of
1949 as  amended, and the  Debt Recovery Special Provisions Act No. 2 of 1990. These have
continued to be dependent on the court system. As such, they cannot offer to SMEs improved
access  to  credit  based  on  movable  property  collateral.  This  is  because  even  in  industrial
countries with refined security interest regimes, a court’s disposition time can be too long and
will  not  allow  total  collection  time  and  costs  to  come  within  a  range  that  would  allow  movable
property to effectively serve as collateral for credit.  Even efforts on so-called parate execution
remedy  for  creditors  outside  the  court  system  have  been  restricted  to  particular  financial
institutions. The inability of such reforms to fuel SME development is not unexpected since such
partial reform of the secured transactions regime actually limits access to credit by hampering
nonbank creditors, who extend credit to SME clients in whom banks have limited or no interest.

8.

Limited Use of IT by SMEs

45.
IT can help SMEs by reducing the costs of doing business, improving linkages with the
global  economy,  and  spreading  information  and  knowledge  to  remote  areas.  The  limited
telecommunications  infrastructure  is  a  major  constraint  to  growth  of  IT  applications.  The
absence of a level playing field for commercial users and providers of telecommunications, and
the virtual monopoly of voice telecommunications held by Sri Lanka Telecom (SLT) compound
this problem and are reflected in the relatively high cost of telephone communications. The legal
framework is yet to be firmly established and language is perceived to be a barrier to growth of
the sector as is the scarcity of trained human resources.

46.
Aside from the onetime costs associated with computer purchase, the greatest barrier to
the take-up of the Internet is the recurring costs associated with Internet access. Typically, 15
hours  of  local  call  time  to  a  provider  will  cost  $13.05  per  month.  Over  the  full  year,  call
connection  charges  alone  will  amount  to  $156.60,  or  20  percent  of  gross  national  product  per
capita. This places Internet use well beyond the reach of the average Sri Lankan. SLT’s role as
the  only  purveyor  of  voice  communications  is  partly  responsible  for  these  high  costs.  In
particular,  its  monopoly  of  the  independent  gateway  prevents  the  possibility  for  reductions  in
internet access costs.  Without these reductions, even simple innovations such as internet cafes
are unlikely to flourish.

D.

 Government Objectives and Strategy

47.
The  Government  sees  private  sector  development  as  the  main  means  of  achieving
sustainable  economic  growth  and  reaching  its  Vision  2010  target  of  7-8  percent  growth  per
annum.    Reforms  have  been  undertaken  related  to  private  and  SMEs  development  with  the
assistance  of  ADB,  e.g.,  through  the  Private  Sector  Development  Program  adopted  in  2000.
These  reforms  have  contributed  to  financial  sector  development,  privatization,  reducing  labor
market rigidities, and promoting competition. However, Sri Lanka still faces challenges related to
diversification  of  the  economy,  improving  competitiveness,  and  expanding  employment

 12

opportunities.  The  Government  feels  that  SMEs  will  play  an  increasingly  important  role  in
meeting these challenges.

48.
In  view  of  the  importance  of  SMEs  to  the  economy,  the  Government  is  embarking  on
further  policy  and  institutional  reforms  to  create  a  dynamic  SME  sector.  It  is  felt  that  a  new
strategy is needed to contend with the emerging challenges both domestically and abroad. The
importance of providing a level playing field in terms of a more conducive business environment
free of bureaucratic impediments is recognized. In addition, over the long term the Government
will reform tax (and customs) administration.  A key concern is that rigidities in these institutions
promote  evasion  and  informality  generally  while  being  especially  onerous  for  SMEs.
Furthermore,  they  continue  to  constrain  the  free  and  efficient  flow  of  goods  and  services  and
hence limit the gains from policy reform. This represents recognition, and reversal, of a reform
strategy  that  ignored  these  institutions  while  seeking  to  compensate  for  their  shortcomings  by
creating  parallel  regimes  for  tax  (and  customs)  maintained  by  BOI.  This  process  is  initiated
under  SMESDP  which  both  completes  important  reforms  of  the  tax  system  and,  through  the
Deregulation Committee, provides a mechanism for managing further regulatory reform over the
medium term.

49.
It  is  recognized  also  that  shrinking  public  sector  budgets  no  longer  permit  large-scale
provision  of  subsidized  assistance  to  promote  SMEs.  At  the  same  time  the  Government  is
aware  that  absence  of  full  and  efficient  markets  in  capacity  building  and  finance  for  SMEs
remains important bottlenecks to the sector. In this context the Government’s strategy stresses
the development of efficient markets for business services for SMEs. This will be balanced, over
the  longer  term,  by  the  rationalization  and  downsizing  of  IDB,  the  major  conduit  for  public
provision  of  BDS.  While  the  public  sector  will  play  an  important  role  in  managing  the  reform
process, a greater  stress is  placed  on private sector and SME inputs in the policy formulation
and decision-making process.

In  terms  of  access  to  finance  the  Government’s  strategy  is  to  promote  greater

Rationale

5.
Traditionally, SME development relied on direct and subsidized provision of financial and
nonfinancial services to SMEs. One drawback to this direct approach is that it has no significant
reach.  A  typical  project  staff  consists  of  a  few  professionals  who  can  directly  reach  a  limited
number of SMEs. A second, more detrimental aspect of the direct approach is that it tends to
undercut  the  emergence  of  a  local  BDS  industry.  The  development  of  an  indigenous  BDS
industry permits permanency and reach that no time-bound project can attain.

6.
The  SMESDP  design  purposely  includes  three  critical  factors  that  will  enable  SMEs  to
grow:  appropriate  enabling  environment,  access  to  necessary  capital,  and  provision  of  BDS.
The integrated model to SME development seeks to amend the provision of credit financing with
a  strong  BDS  provider  market  as  a  means  of  stimulating  SME  development.  This  will  be
achieved  via  the  BSSF,  which  will  complement  the  policy  and  regulatory  and  SME  finance
components of the SMESDP loan.

period.  Capital growth has kept pace with the growth in loans and deposits to meet and exceed
the CBSL capital adequacy standards. CBSL currently requires a 9 percent Tier 1 and 2 capital
adequacy  ratio.  During  1996-2000,  Sampath  maintained  a  Tier  I  and  II  capital  adequacy  ratio
between 12 percent and 14 percent. Having done that, Sampath’s capital adequacy percentage
dropped from 14 percent to about 12 percent at end-2000. This could be a cause for concern if
the  trend  continues.  The  existence  of  rising  nonperforming  loans  approaching  15  percent  is
further reason for a cautious and careful review of Sampath’s 2001 annual financial statements
after year-end.

28.
The  CBSL  liquidity  reserve  requirement  is  20  percent.  In  practice,  banks  must  stay
above this to avoid even short-term liquidity dips below this standard. Sampath has maintained
a  liquidity  ratio  very  close  to  the  CBSL  limit.  At  end-1999,  Sampath’s  ratio  of  liquid  assets  to
liabilities  stood  at  20.27  percent.  By  end-2000,  Sampath’s  liquidity  ratio  had  risen  to  21.16
percent.

29.
Sampath has also had some difficulty with nonperforming loans. Its nonperforming loans
rose  following  the  1997  economic  slowdown,  with  the  nonperforming  loan  percentage  of  the
total loan portfolio of 7.6 percent going to 10.8 by end-1998. Along with rapid growth in its loan
portfolio  came  additional  bad  loans.  During  1999,  Sampath’s  nonperforming  loans  grew  even
higher to 17.1 percent. Sampath managed to bring the rate down to 12.9 percent by end- 2000,
but it recently crept up again to 14.7 percent. A more detailed review of the type and quality of
loans that are showing up in the nonperforming category may shed some light on new strategies
for improving the bank’s performance. It may be that its aggressive bank pioneering strategies
into new products and services has also brought Sampath in contact with many new customers
that  have  not  previously  had  bank  loans.  Some  loans  to  new  borrowers,  if  not  carefully
managed  and  aggressively  collected  immediately  upon  default  of  payment,  gradually  become
loss loans. The key is having the proper credit criteria in analyzing the loans prior to approval
and an early warning system that gives the first signs of problems.

30.
Sampath is well aware of the nonperforming loan problem and has provisioned general
and  specific  reserves  against  loss.  At  end-2000,  Sampath  had  a  loan  loss  provision  that
covered  31  percent  of  its  nonperforming  loan  portfolio.  Nevertheless,  the  recent  upsurge  in
more  nonperforming  loans  suggests  a  review  of  this  problem  at  year-end  to  assess  its
temporary or long-term nature. Sampath’s five-year performance suggests that workout of these
nonperforming loans may take some time and will continue to be pressing down on Sampath’s
profitability.

D.

National Development Bank

 

1.

Background

31.
The National Development Bank (NDB) was established as a wholly state owned special
financial institution by an Act of Parliament in 1979. The Government offered 61 percent of its
capital to the public for sale in February 1993 and to institutional investors in accordance with
privatization  of  the  government’s  controlling  interest.  The  Government  further  reduced  its

 78

Appendix 9, page 7

ownership  interest  in  1997  to  12.2  percent  through  a  convertible  debentures  offering.  An
additional 2.56 percent of the Government’s share was transferred to the employee share option
scheme. NDB is now widely held by approximately 7,000 shareholders and its approximately 54
million  shares  are  traded  on  the  CSE.  The  five  largest  shareholders  include  the  Government
(Secretary  to  the  Treasury)  (7.33  percent),  BSDT—Investors  Pacific  International  Fund  (6.84
percent), Bank of Ceylon (6.11 percent), CBSL (4.88 percent), and Hong Kong Shanghai Bank
Corporation  Int’l  Nominees  (3.71  percent).  NDB  is  regulated  by  CBSL.  CBSL’s  continued
ownership  interest,  probably  a  vestige  of  NDB’s  state-owned  status,  would  appear  to  be  a
conflict of interest between NDB and its regulator.

32.
NDB continues to operate under its enabling statute as a public development institution.
Due to a recent purchase of ABN-AMRO Bank (Sri Lanka) changed to NDB, NDB has long-term
plans to merge with the NDB Bank and become a universal commercial bank. This process will
require  amending  its  statute  to  permit  the  merger  and  regulatory  approval.  NDB  has  been
pursuing a strategy for becoming a dominant provider of a whole range of financial products and
services to its customers, including those offered by commercial banks. A group identified with
NDB  will  be  supported  through  a  common  IT  platform  and  administration.  Consolidation  with
NDB is one step in NDB’s long-term strategy.

 

2.

Organization, Management, and Personnel

33.
NDB  is  managed  by  a  board  of  directors  of  11  members  comprising  of  experienced
national  and  international  business  people,  financiers,  and  bankers.  The  ADB  resident
representative  in  Sri  Lanka,  Mr.  Cooney,  sits  on  the  NDB  board.  The  NDB  managing  director
and chief executive officer is also an ex officio nonvoting board member.

34.
trained
NDB  has  historically  been  staffed  with  a  high  percentage  of  highly 
professionals—engineers, Masters of Business Administration graduates, economists, lawyers,
and accountants to give hands-on project finance team management to the majority of its past
lending  activities.  The  total  staff  increased  from  223  in  1996  to  376  in  2000  a  67  percent
increase during the period. In addition to project finance, NDB is involved in a number of related
financial  areas,  including  merchant  banking  (share  underwriting,  loan  syndication,  diagnostic
and  feasibility  studies,  and  financial  advisory  services),  equipment  leasing  and  finance,  and
working capital finance.

35.
Like the commercial banks, NDB trains its staff in-house in all areas of bank operations
and procedures. NDB employee training is also supplemented with participation in courses and
seminars conducted by CBSL and private banking institutes.

36.
NDB purchased software and hardware for a comprehensive IT system to modernize IT
across the NDB group. By year-end, NDB and its 11-branch network will be fully automated and
computer-linked to enable information flow throughout the group.

3.

Operations

37.
Like  the  commercial  banks,  NDB  also  experienced  high  growth  in  total  assets  during
1996-2000, except in the last year. NDB’s total assets have not quite doubled but increased 92
percent  during  the  past  five  years  from  SLRs19.9  billion  in  1996  to  SLRs38.3  billion,  with  an
annual  asset  growth  range  of  19-32  percent  for  the  first  four  years.  Total  assets  grew  by  only
2.9 percent from 1999 to 2000, reflecting the very modest increase in total loans that year. Total
loans  and  advances  also  rose  rapidly  during  the  period  except  for  the  flatness  in  2000:  from

 79

Appendix 9, page 8

SLRs14.7 billion in 1996 doubling to almost SLRs28.5 billion in 1999 before turning flat with a
14  percent  increase  in  2000  with  SLRs28.59  billion  total  loans  and  advances.  The  decline  in
demand was reflected in the drop in loan approvals in both 1999 and 2000. Loan approvals in
1999  dropped  34  percent  from  1998  and  a  steeper  decline  of  38  percent  occurred  in  2000.
Management explains this as related to the bank’s effort to regularize some short-term facilities
and its desire to curtail new lending in short-term instruments.

38.
NDB  is  not  a  deposit-taking  institution  but  has  been  funded  by  a  series  of  long-term
credit facilities from the Government and multilateral banks. It is a private enterprise, resulting
from the Government’s privatizating all but less than 10 percent of its ownership interest. NDB is
responding to the challenge to obtain alternative funding sources and trying to more efficiently
manage its current resources to obtain greater profitability.

 

4.

Financial Performance, Position, and Portfolio Quality

39.
NDB’s  income  rose  along  with  the  asset  and  loan  growth  of  1996-2000,  increasing
annually  at  12-23  percent.  Income  for  end-1998  stood  at  SLRs2.8  billion  growing  to  SLRs5.2
billion by 2000. Profitability has been more illusive for NDB. Profit rose from SLRs707 million in
1996 to SLRs774 million in 1998, only to decline (4.5 percent) to SLRs739 million in 1999 and
further decline (29 percent) to SLRs519 million in 2000. The NDB decline in profitability during
the five-year period is more clearly illustrated  by its declining return on average assets, which
went from 3.4 percent in 1996 steadily downward each year—3.1 percent in 1997, 2.8 percent
in  1998,  2.2  percent  in  1999,  and  finally  to  1.4  percent  in  2000.  This  steady  decline  reflects
NDB’s  change  in  status  to  a  private  enterprise.  The  signals  are  clear  that  it  must  turn  its
profitability decline around quickly or its ability to continue to operate as a going concern may be
in jeopardy.

40.
NDB  must  quickly  find  alternative  funding  sources  for  its  projects.  It  is  not  clear  that
entering  the  retail  commercial  banking  world  to  gather  deposits  is  necessarily  the  answer.
Though  deposit  mobilization  has  experienced  rapid  growth  during  the  last  five  years,  it  is  not
clear that there are sufficient additional funds from the population that are not already housed in
one or more of the depository gathering institutions. Bidding away deposits from other financial
institutions can be expensive, particularly when NDB is behind in developing a branch network.

41.
More  importantly,  NDB  must  resolve  its  declining  loan  approvals  that  have  been  the
mainstay  of  its  business.  If  that  business  cannot  be  revived,  alternative  intermediation  or  fee-
earning  opportunities  must  be  developed  and  quickly.  Should  NDB’s  profitability  continue  to
decline, it will become increasingly more difficult for the bank to reverse the trend.

 

5.

Capital Adequacy, Liquidity, and Equity

42.
NDB  was  initially  strongly  capitalized  from  government  sources  and  continued  to  have
ample capital to support its services during its early stages through privatization. From the initial
capital  of  SLRs175  million,  NDB  increased  its  capital  to  SLRs358  million  in  1997  through
convertible debentures. A further share offering in 2000 raised NDB’s paid-in capital to SLRs538
million  (Table  A9.2).  From  this  shareholder  base,  NDB  has  developed  the  bulk  of  its  capital
resources  to  support  its  loan  and  asset  growth  through  retained  earnings.  Total  capital  has
grown from SLRs4.1 billion in 1996 to SLRs5.78 billion in 2000, or a 41 percent increase for the
period.  Throughout  the  period,  NDB  reported  a  strong  capital  adequacy  position,  more  than
meeting the CBSL capital adequacy standards. During 1996-2000, NDB maintained a Tier I and
II  capital  adequacy  ratio  between  21  period  and  13  period,  substantially  above  the  CBSL

 80

Appendix 9, page 9

standard.  The  downward  trend  is  somewhat  problematic  and  needs  serious  attention.  The
decline simply confirms the other downward trends in NDB’s business that must be addressed
before capital levels go substantially lower and more difficult to correct.

NDB also has substantial nonperforming loans during the past two years. Although the
43.
percentage  of  nonperforming  loans  is  declining,  it  is  still  high  and  must  be  redressed  soon  in
face  of  the  bank’s  generally  declining  profitability  trend.  More  information  on  the  amount  and
character  of  the  nonperforming  loans  at  year-end  is  needed  to  determine  whether  there  is
further deterioration in the bank’s portfolio or condition.

E.

DFCC BANK

1. 

Background

44.
DFCC  was  established  by  an  Act  of  Parliament  in  1955  as  a  public  limited-liability
company to provide financial assistance principally to the private industry and service sectors of
Sri  Lanka.  Operations  began  in  May  1956.  Through  the  Bank  of  Ceylon  and  Sri  Lanka
Insurance  Corporation—Life  Fund,  the  Government  owns  17.65  percent  of  DFCC,  with  the
remainder held by the public and institutional investors with a total of 7,419 shareholders. The
five  largest  DFCC  shareholders  are  Bank  of  Ceylon  (15  percent),  HNB  (9.15  percent),  DEG
(7.84  percent),  Readywear  Industries  Ltd.  (7.62  percent),  and  Boston  Safe  Deposit  Trust—
Investor Global Fund (6.09 percent).

45.
DFCC  continues  to  operate  under  its  enabling  statute  as  a  public  development
institution. It has been in discussing with CBC a potential consolidation or merger to enable the
broadening  of  DFCC/CBC  into  a  universal  bank.  DFCC  owns  just  under  30  percent  of  CBC.
CBSL Bank Supervision estimated that this process will require amending its statute to permit
the merger and regulatory approval.

2.

Organization, Management, and Personnel

46.
DFCC  is  managed  under  the  direction  of  a  board  of  director  comprising  10  members,
responsible for formulating policies and procedures under which the chief executive officer and
an  executive  management  team  of  52  professional  managers  conduct  the  bank’s  operations.
The DFCC chief executive officer is also an ex officio nonvoting board member.

DFCC  has  a  network  of  eight  branches  throughout  Sri  Lanka  through  which  regional

47.
operations are conducted.

3.

Operations

48.
Like  the  other  banks,  DFCC  also  experienced  high  growth  in  total  assets  during  the
period  1997-2001.1  DFCC’s  total  assets  have  not  grown  as  rapidly  as  those  of  the  other
institutions, however, but increased 69 percent during the past five years, from SLRs17.0 billion
in 1997 to SLRs25.9 billion in 2001. The growth was erratic-11 percent to 32 percent until 1999
and  then  remaining  essentially  flat  through  2001.  This  may  reflect  the  changing  in  role  of
development  finance  institutions  from  public  institutions  to  private  enterprises.  Total  loans  and
advances also rose, but not as rapidly as those of other institutions. DFCC‘s loan portfolio grew

from SLRs9 billion in 1997 to almost double, with a 93 percent increase to SLRs17.4 billion in
2001.

49.
DFCC, like NDB, is not a deposit-taking institution, but was funded by a series of long-
term  credit  facilities  from  the  Government  and  multilateral  banks.  Recently,  DFCC  has
experienced rising interest rates on its debt obligations, but is unable to raise its loan rates by
the  same amount. Its net interest rate margin is tightening and putting  downward pressure on
earnings.

4. 

Financial Performance, Position, and Portfolio Quality

50.
DFCC’s income performance has been erratic, rising in 1997 from the previous year by a
modest 6.4 percent and again rising in 1998 by 15 percent. Income rose slowly by 7 percent in
1999 but experienced a larger rise of 17% in 2000 before dropping to 0 percent in 2001. Profit
was equally erratic. Experiencing a profit curve similar to that of NDB, DFCC saw its profit rise
from SLRs416 million in 1997 to SLRs672 million in 1999, only to decline to SLRs530 million in
2000 and further decline (29 percent) to SLRs519 million in 2001.

51.
Though DFCC has not reported its multiyear volume of nonperforming loans, it said that
they were 22 percent of the loan portfolio in 2000 and were down from the previous year. This is
a very high volume  of  nonperforming loans, but is not unusual for a government development
finance  company.  The  difficulty  is  that  DFCC  has  become  a  public  company  and  subject  to
fierce  competition  from  the  private  sector.  Historically,  DFCC  has  taken  the  policy  position  of
trying  to  work  with  a  project  until  there  are  no  options  but  to  foreclose  and  liquidate.  This
explains,  according  to  management,  the  long  time  that  nonperforming  loans  remain  on  the
DFCC books before liquidation. DFCC may have to revisit this policy if it is going to improve its
profitability,  given  the  erratic  trends  of  the  past  five  years.  DFCC  has  a  strong  capital  position
and time to review and reconsider its policies and strategies. In any event, nonperforming loans
at 22 percent are too much of a drag on profitability and should be resolved.

5. 

Capital Adequacy, Liquidity, and Equity

DFCC  reports  a  small  but  steady  capital  growth  throughout  the  review  period.  Total
52.
capital rose 16 percent from 1997 to 1998 but only 7-8 percent annually for the remainder of the
period.  Importantly,  DFCC  has  maintained  a  strong  capital  structure  and  these  modest
increases still enable DFCC to have a capital adequacy ratio exceeding 25 percent for 2000 and
2001.

53.
On  a  longer  term,  DFCC  just  like  NDB,  must  focus  on  its  profitability.  However,  the
picture is not so bleak. DFCC reports return on average assets from 2.6 percent in 1997 up to
3.3 percent in 1998 only to see a decline in the following two years. DFCC recovered in 2001,
improving profitability to 2.5 percent. DFCC appears to be very focused on its profitability picture
and  the  necessary  reductions  in  both  interest  expense  and  operating  expense  to  maintain  its
business and increase profitability.

POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

1.
While  Sri  Lanka  suffers  from  an  acute  absence  of  relevant  data  sources,  poverty  or
socioeconomic  impact  assessments  are  difficult  to  make  even  under  normal  circumstance  as
the level of detail required in the data is expensive to create and collect. This latter factor has
sharply  constrained  the  value  of  impact  assessments  globally,  and  has  been  recognized  as
such by the International Financial Institutions Working Group on SMEs. The Small and Medium
Enterprise  Sector  Development  Program  (SMESDP)  addresses  this  issue  by  building  in  a
comprehensive  set  of  socioeconomic  indicators  to  be  collected  in  a  computerized  format  by
PCIs at subloan approval stage.  This will provide a unique basis for carrying out post evaluation
of the project’s impact.

A.

Estimate of Job Creation

2.
The coefficient  of 553 jobs per $1 million of loans estimated from earlier SME projects
financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  Sri  Lanka  was  adjusted  downward  by  20
percent to reflect the higher loan size under SMESDP to obtain an estimate of 447 jobs per $1
million of loans (rounded to 450 jobs). Since the project proposes to disburse altogether $150
million in credit assistance, the estimated total new employment created is about 62,000.

3.
This estimate should, however, be treated as a gross estimate. A separate World Bank
assessment of its projects in Sri Lanka found that nearly 40 percent of the borrowers go out of
business  within  eight  years  of  receiving  loans  (consistent  with  figures  from  developed
economies). To that extent, a part of the new job creation is temporary in nature. By applying
the figure of 40 percent as the extent of temporary job creation, the net employment generated
under SMESDP is predicted to be 40,000.

B.

The Impact of SME Development on Open Unemployment

4.
In  view  of  the  capacity  of  SMEs  to  create  jobs  at  a  relatively  low  cost,  any  program  of
SME development would be expected to help relieve the unemployment problem under normal
circumstances. In Sri Lanka, however, the factors that tend to render the rate of unemployment
high  and  resilient  are  also  the  factors  that  are  likely  to  dampen  the  unemployment-reducing
effect of job creation through SMEs.

Unemployment  is  high  because  a  large  number  of  educated  young  people  search  for
5.
jobs over an extended time, waiting for “appropriate” jobs. These people tend to seek salaried
“secure  jobs,”  primarily  in  the  public  sector.  It  is  unlikely  that  large  numbers  of  these
unemployed  will  want  to  be  become  entrepreneurs,  at  least  initially.  This  is  not  to  say  that
educated  people  do  not  become  SME  entrepreneurs  or  that  the  SME  entrepreneurs  are  not
educated. As  many  as 85 percent  of  SME entrepreneurs have at least high school education.
However,  the  majority  of  entrepreneurs  (78  percent)  came  from  families  that  had  a  business
background. These findings suggest that, generally speaking, educated young people are more
likely to set up SMEs if there is a family tradition of doing so.

6.
While  there  is  still  stress  on  secure  public  sector  jobs  among  the  educated,  an
examination  of  the  Sri  Lankan  experience  during  the  postliberalization  period  suggests  that  a
cultural change has already begun—educated young people are beginning to set up their own
small businesses. The components of the proposed SME project that seek to promote market
development by providing business development service (BDS) and information technology (IT)

 88

Appendix 11, page 2

services will stimulate this process of transformation. Not only will the educated youth be drawn
to  entrepreneurial  activities  by  the  presence  of  efficient  service  providers,  they  will  also  be
increasingly absorbed in the service-providing establishments themselves.

The process of cultural change is likely to be slow. With the declining importance of the
7.
public  sector  in  the  Sri  Lankan  economy,  this  sector’s  share  in  total  employment  came  down
sharply  over  the  1990s.  However,  the  loss  of  public  sector  employees  has  been  offset  almost
entirely  by  the  gain  of  privates  sector  employees—with  very  little  change  in  the  proportion  of
self-employed  people  (Table  A11.1).  People  have  swapped  the  security  of  white-collar  public
sector jobs with the security of white-collar private sector jobs.

8.

C.

The Gender Dimension of Poverty

Substantial  evidence  indicates  the  absence  of  any  serious  gender  discrimination  in
9.
intrahousehold  allocation  of  resources.  To  the  extent  that  the  treatment  of  female  children  is
indicative  of  the  treatment  of  women  in  general,  it  is  reasonable  to  conclude  that  gender
discrimination  in  the  allocation  of  household  resources  is  not  a  serious  problem  in  Sri  Lanka.
Accordingly,  there  is  no  reason  to  suspect  that  female  poverty  is  more  serious  than  male
poverty within the same household.

10.
However, while Sri Lanka has one of the highest gender development index (GDI) in the
developing  world,  its  gender  empowerment  index  (GEM)  is  slightly  lower  than  the  average  for
developing countries. In 1994, for instance, Sri Lanka’s GDI was 69 percent compared with 55
percent for the developing world as a whole, while GEM was 31 percent against the developing
world average of 37 percent. The low share of earned income is one of the factors, but not only
one, that keeps GEM low. It also contributes to keeping GDI well below the parity figure of 100
percent, because the share of earned income is a component of GDI as well. In terms of other
components of GDI –viz. health and education—Sri Lanka has already achieved near parity. It

 89

Appendix 11, page 3

is only the component of earned income share that prevents achievement of full gender equality
in human development.

11.
Therefore,  any  contribution  that  the  SME  sector  can  make  to  create  income-earning
opportunities for women will help achieve gender parity in both development and empowerment.
If the sector can also absorb more women in administrative/managerial and technical positions,
that will also help in improving their empowerment as measured by the GEM index.

Females are not disadvantaged compared with men in terms of poverty or generally in
12.
terms  of  human  deprivation,  but  they  are  clearly  disadvantaged  in  terms  of  employment
prospects.  It  is  in  this  background  that  the  probable  gender  impact  of  the  proposed  SME
development project must be analyzed. The relevant issue then is not so much how the Project
affects women’s poverty, but rather how it will address women’s disadvantage in the sphere of
employment.

13.
Evidence from the labor force surveys shows that it is the young adult females in the age
group of 15-30 years that are most severely afflicted by the problem of unemployment. These
are mostly women with high school education. Table A11.2 shows that rates of unemployment
are highest among those with education levels of 9-10 years of schooling to the A-levels. It is
this group of young educated women who will have to be absorbed if the SME sector is to make
any  significant  contribution  in  addressing  the  problem  of  female  disadvantage  in  the
employment sphere.

14.
Unemployed women with high school education should constitute a rich pool of potential
entrepreneurs  in  the  small  and  medium-scale  sector.  But  in  reality,  women  entrepreneurs  are
seriously  underrepresented  in  the  SME  sector.  A  recent  study  found  that  from  1979  to  1995,
only 1 percent of the beneficiary firms and 5 percent of nonbeneficiary firms under ADB-World
Bank financed credit lines had women entrepreneurs. These figures are in sharp contrast with
the  fact  that  women  represent  as  much  as  18  percent  of  the  self-employed  labor  force  in  the
country.

These figures suggest that while the smaller end of the SME spectrum may not prove to
be a major source of paid employment for women, the upper end of the spectrum might be. In

This  will  not  significantly  ameliorate  the  problem  of  open  unemployment  among
18.

accept  blue-collar  jobs.  But  women  with  less  education  (primary  level  or  less),  who  do  not

underemployment  and  disguised  unemployment  among  women,  in  much  the  same  way  as  in
the case of men.  In other words, the proposed project is likely to be characterized by gender
neutrality  in  its  positive  impact  on  the  problems  of  underemployment  and  disguised
unemployment in Sri Lanka.

19.
One  way  in  which  the  project  is  likely  to  have  a  bigger  impact  on  women  than  men  is
through migratory flows, which may mitigate to some extent the effect of the likely concentration
of  SME  activities  in  Western  Province.  Through  these  flows,  the  poor  of  outlying  districts  and
provinces  will  share  in  the  beneficial  effect  of  the  SME  project  even  if  the  immediate  impact
happens to be concentrated in a few districts. Women tend to benefit more than men from this
process.  An  analysis  of  the  socioeconomic  profiles  of  migrants,  based  on  the  1994  Labour
Force Survey, shows that the sex ratio (male-to-female) is lower among migrants than among
non-migrants residing in the districts of Colombo and Gampaha, the two most commercialized
and industrialized districts of the country. This indicates that females migrate more than men in
search  of  employment,  and  as  such  should  benefit  proportionately  more  from  the  creation  of
employment opportunities in industry sector in general and the SME sector in particular.

20.
The reform of  the  legal  system under the project to enable potential borrowers to offer
movable property (including work-in-progress, collectibles, etc.) as collateral is likely to benefit
women proportionately more, also. This would help women borrowers in particular, as they are
especially  disadvantaged  in  their  access  to  immovable  property.  But  they  would  need  further
assistance if they are to break away from the traditional gender stereotyping of occupations.
